abstract.p: Aaron Crowell letter says Paul Krugman (May 10 Op-Ed) overestimates ability of free markets to bring real democratic change without motivation from China's leadership (S)

block.p: Although Paul Krugman (''A Symbol Issue,'' column, May 10) correctly points out that Deng Xiaoping was not altruistically motivated when he moved to modernize China, he overestimates the ability of free markets to bring real democratic change without such motivations from China's leadership.
Since the 18th century, various Chinese governments have been careful to prevent Western-style economic reform from bringing about similar government, intellectual or moral reforms.

Although Paul Krugman (''A Symbol Issue,'' column, May 10) correctly points out that Deng Xiaoping was not altruistically motivated when he moved to modernize China, he overestimates the ability of free markets to bring real democratic change without such motivations from China's leadership.
Since the 18th century, various Chinese governments have been careful to prevent Western-style economic reform from bringing about similar government, intellectual or moral reforms.
This continuing separation has allowed for improvements like Deng's ''four modernizations,'' all of which are economic or military, without any concurrent democratic developments.
There is no reason to believe that anything short of the rejection of ''permanent normal trade relations,'' symbolic as it may be, will change this situation.
